title: How Stocks Are Traded
description: Go behind the scenes to understand the difference between the primary and secondary markets, and the key players involved in every transaction.

hero.title: The Mechanics of Stock Trading
hero.subtitle: From IPO to Daily Trading
hero.description: Understanding how stocks are traded is essential for any investor. This lesson will take you through the entire process, from when a company first goes public to how millions of shares change hands every day.

primarySecondary.title: Primary vs. Secondary Markets
primarySecondary.p1: Stock trading happens in two distinct markets, each serving a different purpose in the financial ecosystem:

primary.title: The Primary Market
primary.p: This is where stocks are born. When a company holds an Initial Public Offering (IPO), it sells its shares directly to investors for the first time. The money goes directly to the company.
features: Shares are sold for the first time

secondary.title: The Secondary Market
secondary.p: This is what we typically call 'the stock market.' It's where investors trade stocks among themselves without the company's involvement. The price is determined by supply and demand.

tradingProcess.title: The Complete Trading Process
tradingProcess.p1: Understanding the step-by-step process helps demystify how your buy and sell orders are executed:

step1.title: Place Your Order
step1.description: You place a buy or sell order through your broker's platform

step2.title: Order Routing
step2.description: Your broker routes the order to the appropriate exchange

step3.title: Order Matching
step3.description: The exchange matches your order with a willing seller/buyer

step4.title: Trade Execution
step4.description: Your order is executed and shares are transferred

keyPlayers.title: The Key Players in Stock Trading
keyPlayers.p1: Several entities work together to make stock trading possible:

exchanges.title: Stock Exchanges
exchanges.p: These are the organized marketplaces where trading occurs. In India, the two main exchanges are the National Stock Exchange (NSE) and the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE).

brokers.title: Stock Brokers
brokers.p: Retail investors can't trade directly on an exchange. They need a licensed intermediary called a stockbroker (like Zerodha, Upstox, etc.) to execute trades on their behalf.

depositories.title: Depositories
depositories.p: These institutions hold your shares electronically in demat accounts. In India, we have NSDL and CDSL.

clearingCorporations.title: Clearing Corporations
clearingCorporations.p: These ensure that all trades are settled properly and on time. They act as a central counterparty.

orderTypes.title: Understanding Order Types
orderTypes.p1: Different order types give you control over how and when your trades are executed:

marketOrder.title: Market Orders
marketOrder.description: Execute immediately at the best available price
marketOrder.bestFor: When you need immediate execution and price is less important

limitOrder.title: Limit Orders
limitOrder.description: Execute only at your specified price or better
limitOrder.bestFor: When you want to control the price and can wait for execution

stopLoss.title: Stop Loss Orders
stopLoss.description: Automatically sell when price falls below a certain level

tradingSessions.title: Trading Sessions and Timings
tradingSessions.p1: Stock markets operate during specific hours with different phases:

marketOpen.title: Market Opening
marketOpen.description: Opening auction to determine opening prices

marketClose.title: Market Closing
marketClose.description: Closing auction for final price discovery

settlementProcess.title: The Settlement Process
settlementProcess.p1: After a trade is executed, several steps happen to complete the transaction:

tPlus1.title: T+1 Day (Trade Day + 1)
tPlus1.description: Shares and money are transferred between accounts

importantNotes: Settlement is now T+1 in India (faster than global T+2)
Shares are held in electronic form (demat)

tradingCosts.title: Understanding Trading Costs
tradingCosts.p1: Several costs are involved in stock trading that affect your returns:

brokerage.title: Brokerage Charges
brokerage.description: Fees charged by your broker for executing trades

costOptimization.title: Cost Optimization Tips
strategies: Use limit orders to avoid slippage

riskManagement.title: Risk Management in Trading
riskManagement.p1: Trading involves risks that can be managed with proper strategies:

marketRisk.title: Market Risk
marketRisk.description: Overall market movements affecting your stocks

liquidityRisk.title: Liquidity Risk
liquidityRisk.description: Difficulty in buying or selling stocks quickly

executionRisk.title: Execution Risk
executionRisk.description: Orders not executing at expected prices
mitigation: Avoid market orders for large quantities

bestPractices.title: Best Practices for Stock Trading
bestPractices.p1: Follow these guidelines to become a better trader:

planning.title: Plan Your Trades
planning.description: Always have a clear plan before entering a trade

discipline.title: Maintain Discipline
discipline.description: Stick to your trading plan regardless of emotions

education.title: Continuous Learning
education.description: Never stop learning about markets and trading

takeaways.title: Key Takeaways
items: The Primary Market is for new stocks (IPOs), where money goes to the company.
The Secondary Market is where investors trade existing stocks with each other.
You need a broker to trade on the major stock exchanges like NSE and BSE.
Understanding order types helps you control how and when your trades execute.
The settlement process ensures safe and secure transfer of shares and money.
Proper risk management is essential for long-term trading success.
